definition[0]: to pretend something, especially in order to achieve what you want in a difficult or dangerous situation
note[0]: bluff somebody into (doing) something (=make someone do something by deceiving them)
example[0]: You wouldn’t really tell her. You’re bluffing!
example[1]: ‘I was with Don, ’ she said, deciding to bluff it out  (=continue to pretend something).
example[2]: I hope we’ll be able to bluff our way past the guard.
note[1]: bluff your way out of/through/past etc somebody/something
definition[1]: an attempt to deceive someone by making them think you will do something, when you do not intend to do it
example[3]: The threat was only a bluff.
example[4]: Whatever you say, you must do it. This isn’t a game of bluff.
definition[2]: a very steep cliff or slope
definition[3]: a bluff person, usually a man, is pleasant but very direct and does not always consider other people
example[5]: He was a bluff no-nonsense administrator.
